title: Acknowledge Feelings
summary: Recognize and validate your teen’s emotions before moving to problem-solving or advice.

details.content: Teens are more likely to listen and cooperate when they feel understood. Dismissing or minimizing feelings can lead to resistance or withdrawal.
When your teen says, 'School is so stressful,' respond with, 'It sounds like you’re really overwhelmed right now,' instead of, 'It’s not that bad.'

content: Listen without interrupting.
Name the feeling you observe (e.g., 'You seem frustrated').
Avoid giving advice or reassurance right away.
Use phrases like, 'That sounds tough,' or 'I can see why you’d feel that way.'

title: Engage Cooperation
summary: Invite your teen’s cooperation by describing the problem and expressing your needs clearly, rather than commanding or criticizing.

details.content: Teens are more likely to help when they feel respected and involved, rather than ordered around.
Instead of saying, 'Pick up your clothes right now!' try, 'I’m having trouble vacuuming with clothes on the floor.'

content: Describe what you see or need without blame.
Give information rather than orders.
Offer choices or ask for input.
Express appreciation for cooperation.

title: Alternatives to Punishment
summary: Focus on solutions and learning rather than punishment when problems arise.

details.content: Punishment can breed resentment and rebellion. Alternatives help teens learn responsibility and problem-solving.
If your teen misses curfew, discuss what happened and brainstorm together how to handle it differently next time, instead of grounding them immediately.

content: State your expectations clearly.
Express your feelings and needs.
Offer choices to make amends.
Work together to find solutions.
Allow natural consequences when safe.

title: Encourage Autonomy
summary: Support your teen’s growing independence by allowing them to make choices and solve problems.

details.content: Teens need to develop confidence in their own judgment. Over-controlling can lead to power struggles or dependence.
Instead of telling your teen exactly how to organize their homework, ask, 'What’s your plan for getting your assignments done?'

content: Let teens make age-appropriate decisions.
Encourage problem-solving rather than giving solutions.
Respect their privacy and opinions.
Acknowledge their efforts and progress.

title: Praise and Self-Esteem
summary: Use specific, descriptive praise to build your teen’s self-esteem and motivation.

details.content: Teens benefit from knowing exactly what they did well. Generic praise can feel insincere or unhelpful.
Instead of saying, 'Good job,' say, 'I noticed you spent extra time on your project and it really shows in your work.'

content: Describe what you see and feel ('You put a lot of effort into this').
Focus on effort, progress, and strategies.
Avoid labels like 'smart' or 'talented.'
Encourage self-reflection ('How do you feel about what you accomplished?').

title: Freeing Teens from Playing Roles
summary: Help your teen break free from negative labels and fixed roles by noticing and encouraging positive behaviors.

details.content: Teens often internalize roles like 'the lazy one' or 'the troublemaker.' Highlighting their strengths helps them see themselves differently.
If your teen is usually disorganized but remembers an appointment, say, 'You kept track of the time today—that was responsible.'

content: Notice and comment on positive changes, even small ones.
Avoid repeating negative labels or stories.
Give opportunities for your teen to act differently.
Express confidence in their ability to grow and change.
